raw_text:
Global digital divide 'narrowing'
 
 The "digital divide" between rich and poor nations is narrowing fast, according to a World Bank report.
 
 The World Bank questioned a United Nation's campaign to increase usage and access to technology in poorer nations. "People in the developing world are getting more access at an incredible rate - far faster than... in the past," said the report. But a spokesman for the UN's World Summit on the Information Society said the digital divide remained very real. "The digital divide is rapidly closing," the World Bank report said.
 
 Half the world's population now has access to a fixed-line telephone, the report said, and 77% to a mobile network.
 
 The report's figures surpass a WSIS campaign goal that calls for 50% access to telephones by 2015. The UN hopes that widening access to technology such as mobile phones and the net will help eradicate poverty. "Developing countries are catching up with the rich world in terms of access [to mobile networks]," the report said. "Africa is part of a worldwide trend of rapid rollout... this applies to countries rich and poor, reformed or not, African, Asian, European and Latin American."
 
 A spokesman for the World Summit for the Information Society (WSIS), which is meeting this week in Geneva, told the BBC News website: "The digital divide is very much real and needs to be addressed. "Some financing has to be found to help narrow the divide." On Tuesday, a meeting of the WSIS in Geneva agreed to the creation of a Digital Solitary Fund. "The fund is voluntary and will help finance local community-based projects," said the WSIS spokesman. Under the proposals agreed, voluntary contribution of 1% on contracts obtained by private technology service providers could be made to the Digital Solidarity Fund. The exact financing mechanism of the fund is to be ironed out in the coming days, said the WSIS. Sixty percent of resources collected by the fund will be made available for projects in least developed countries, 30% for projects in developing countries, and 10% for projects in developed countries.
llama3.2:1b:
The "digital divide" between rich and poor nations is narrowing due to increased access to technology such as fixed-line telephones and mobile networks. The World Bank report states that half the world's population now has access to these technologies at a faster rate than previously, with 77% having access to mobile networks by 2015.

The report finds that developing countries are catching up with richer nations in terms of access to technology. Africa is part of a global trend of rapid rollout and expansion of digital connectivity. However, the World Summit for Information Society (WSIS) agreed to establish a Digital Solitary Fund to help narrow the gap in access to technology. The fund will be funded through voluntary contributions from private technology service providers, with 60% of resources going to least developed countries.
llama3.2:3b: The World Bank report says the digital divide between rich and poor nations is narrowing fast, with half the world's population having access to a fixed-line telephone and 77% to a mobile network, surpassing a UN goal of 50% access by 2015. The report states that developing countries are catching up with the rich world in terms of access to mobile networks, citing Africa as part of this trend.
gemma2:2b: The digital divide is shrinking rapidly as more people worldwide gain access to fixed-line phones and mobile networks.  The World Bank reports that over half the global population now has access to a phone line and 77% have access to a mobile network, exceeding goals set by the UN's WSIS campaign. The UN acknowledges the progress but emphasizes that addressing the digital divide remains critical, requiring financial resources for projects like the new Digital Solidarity Fund.
qwen2.5:0.5b: A World Bank report shows that half of the world's population now has access to a fixed-line telephone and mobile networks. The digital divide remains very real despite an UN campaign aiming to increase usage rates and access. A meeting of the WSIS, which is taking place this week in Geneva, agreed on the creation of a Digital Solidarity Fund, which will provide voluntary contributions from private technology service providers towards the fund's financing mechanism.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The global digital divide is narrowing rapidly as access to fixed-line telephones and mobile networks increases significantly worldwide, surpassing UN goals set by the WSIS campaign aimed at increasing phone usage globally. While some argue there remains a persistent gap due to financial constraints, a proposal has been made for a Digital Solidarity Fund to assist in closing this divide.
qwen2.5:3b: Global digital divide is narrowing with half of world's population now having access to fixed-line telephones and 77% to a mobile network. World Bank report suggests that while the gap between rich and poor nations is closing, it remains very real according to UN’s campaign. The Digital Solitary Fund has been created as part of efforts to narrow this divide with voluntary contributions from private technology service providers. Sixty percent of collected funds will go towards projects in least developed countries, 30% for developing countries, and 10% for developed countries.
opencoder:1.5b: The "digital divide" between rich and poor nations is narrowing fast. The World Bank questioned a United Nation's campaign to increase usage and access to technology in poorer nations. People in the developing world are getting more access at an incredible rate - far faster than... in the past. Half the world's population now has access to a fixed-line telephone. The figures surpass a WSIS campaign goal that calls for 50% access to telephones by 2015. Africa is part of a worldwide trend of rapid rollout... this applies to countries rich and poor, reformed or not, African, Asian, European and Latin American. Under the proposals agreed, voluntary contribution of 1% on contracts obtained by private technology service providers could be made to the Digital Solidarity Fund.
smollm:1.7b:
The digital divide is narrowing rapidly across the globe, according to a World Bank report. The report questions a UN campaign goal that calls for 50% access to telephones by 2015. However, half of the world's population now has access to fixed-line telephones and mobile networks. This rapid progress in technology adoption is expected to help eradicate poverty in developing countries.
The World Summit on the Information Society (WSIS) has agreed to create a Digital Solitary Fund to support local community-based projects that promote digital inclusion. The fund will be funded by voluntary contributions from private technology service providers, with 1% of contracts obtained by private companies contributing to the fund. The exact financing mechanism of the fund is to be ironed out in the coming days.
The WSIS has agreed on a target of 50% access to telephones by 2015 for developing countries and 30% for developed countries. This rapid progress in technology adoption will help reduce poverty in developing countries, where half of the population now has access to fixed-line telephones and mobile networks.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, I need to help the user summarize this text concisely while preserving key ideas and details.

First, reading through the original text, it's about the digital divide narrowing between rich and poor nations. The World Bank report says their digital access is increasing rapidly compared to previous times. They mention that half the world has fixed-line phones and 77% have mobile networks now.

The UN's goal for telephones was up to 50%, but the figures show even more, so the UN's campaign isn't meeting its target. The WSIS wants to fund projects in developing countries, especially those in Africa where technology rollout is rapid.

I should focus on the main points: digital divide narrowing, World Bank's report, phone and mobile coverage stats, UN goals not met, WSIS funding for projects in developing areas.

Putting it all together without explanations or formatting as required.
</think>

The digital divide between rich and poor nations has narrowed rapidly according to a World Bank report. The report highlights that half the world's population now has access to fixed-line telephones and 77% have mobile networks, surpassing the UN's target of 50% coverage by 2015. The World Bank's findings suggest rapid progress in digital infrastructure access compared to previous times.
tinyllama:1.1b: The World Bank report states that global digital divides are narrowing rapidly in developing nations. Half of the world's population now has access to fixed-line telephones, while 77% have mobile networks. The WSIS calls for reaching 50% access to telephones by 2015, which is part of a broader trend towards faster internet usage in developing countries. In response to the concerns raised about the digital divide between rich and poor nations, an initiative called the Digital Solidairy Fund has been proposed that will allow private technology service providers to contribute voluntary funds to support community-based projects. The fund's goal is to eradicate poverty by financing local project ideas in least developed countries, developing countries, and developed countries alike. The fund was announced at a meeting of the World Summit for the Information Society (WSIS) taking place this week in Geneva.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
The World Bank report highlights an interesting trend that is affecting global communication and access to technology: the narrowing of the digital divide between rich and poor nations. According to the report, people living in more prosperous regions are enjoying greater usage and access to internet services and mobile networks at a faster rate compared to their counterparts in developing countries. The report suggests that this trend will continue to accelerate as the global campaign to increase internet penetration strives to reach 50% of people by 2015.

The World Bank's study indicates that half of the world's population currently has access to a fixed-line telephone, while over 77% now have mobile networks. This represents a remarkable progress in providing affordable communication services to the masses, particularly in less developed regions.

As a result of this rapid development, widening access to technology such as mobile phones and the internet is expected to help eradicate poverty in developing countries. The WSIS campaign aims to provide 50% access to telephones by 2015, but it is evident that there is still room for improvement. To address this issue, the World Summit on the Information Society (WSIS) has agreed to establish a fund called the Digital Solidarity Fund. The fund will be voluntarily contributed to by private technology service providers and will help fund projects in least developed countries, developing countries, and developed countries that focus on improving access to technology for people in these regions.
phi:2.7b: The World Bank report says that the "digital divide" between rich and poor nations is narrowing fast, with half of the world's population having access to a fixed-line telephone and 77% having access to a mobile network. However, the UN's campaign to increase technology usage and access in poorer nations has been questioned as people in developing countries are getting more access at an incredible rate than before. The report also states that Africa is part of a worldwide trend of rapid rollout of mobile networks, with half the world's population now having access to telephones. The World Summit for the Information Society (WSIS) acknowledges the digital divide but hopes that widening technology access will help eradicate poverty. A Digital Solitary Fund has been created as a voluntary contribution from private technology service providers could be made to finance local community-based projects, with 60% of resources being made available for least developed countries and 30% for developing countries.
orca-mini:3b: The digital divide between rich and poor nations is narrowing fast, according to a World Bank report. Despite efforts by the United Nations to increase access to technology in poorer nations, the digital divide remains very real, according to the report. However, half the world's population now has access to a fixed-line telephone and 77% to a mobile network, which exceeds a WSIS campaign goal of 50% access to telephones by 2015. The report also notes that Africa is part of a worldwide trend of rapid rollout of mobile networks, which applies to countries rich and poor, reformed or not, African, Asian, European, and Latin American. A spokesman for the World Summit on the Information Society (WSIS), which is meeting this week in Geneva, told the BBC News website: "The digital divide is very much real and needs to be addressed. Some financing has to be found to help narrow the divide." The exact financing mechanism of the fund is to be ironed out in the coming days, said the WSIS spokesman.
hermes3:3b: Global digital divide between nations narrowing, according to World Bank report: 50% population has fixed-line telephone access, 77% mobile network access (surpassing UN's 2015 goal of 50% phone access).
stablelm-zephyr:3b: A World Bank report states that the digital divide between rich and poor nations is narrowing rapidly, with half the world's population having access to a fixed-line telephone and 77% to a mobile network. This progress surpasses the United Nations' World Summit on the Information Society goal of achieving 50% access to telephones by 2015. The UN hopes that increasing access to technology like mobile phones and the internet will help reduce poverty. A voluntary Digital Solidarity Fund has been created to finance local community-based projects, with 60% of resources going towards least developed countries, 30% to developing countries, and 10% to developed countries.
stablelm2:1.6b: The digital divide between rich and poor nations is narrowing, according to a World Bank report. Access to technology is increasing rapidly in the developing world, exceeding past rates. Half of the world's population now has access to a fixed-line telephone and 20% to a mobile network. Africa is part of a global trend for rapid rollout across countries rich and poor. The UN aims for widening access such as mobile phones and the internet to eradicate poverty. Funding must be found to address the digital divide, with proposals to create a Digital Solitary Fund that will help finance community-based projects.
granite3.1-dense:2b: The digital divide between wealthy and poor nations is significantly narrowing, as per a World Bank report. The report indicates that half of the global population now has fixed-line phone access and 77% have mobile network access, surpassing the United Nations' campaign target for 2015. This rapid expansion in technology usage is observed across various regions, including Africa, which is experiencing a worldwide trend of rapid telephone rollout. Despite this progress, a spokesperson from the UN's World Summit on the Information Society emphasized that the digital divide remains a pressing issue, necessitating additional financing to further close it. The WSIS, meeting in Geneva, approved the establishment of a Digital Solidarity Fund, with an initial plan for private technology service providers to contribute 1% of their contract values. This fund aims to support community-based projects, allocating 60% to least developed countries, 30% to developing nations, and 10% to developed countries.
chatgpt-4o-latest: The World Bank reports that the global digital divide is narrowing rapidly, with increasing access to technology in developing nations. Half the world's population now has access to fixed-line telephones, and 77% to mobile networks, surpassing UN goals for 2015. The report highlights that developing countries, including those in Africa, are catching up with wealthier nations in mobile network access. However, the UN's World Summit on the Information Society (WSIS) argues that the digital divide remains significant and requires financial support. To address this, WSIS has proposed a voluntary Digital Solidarity Fund to finance local technology projects, with contributions from private technology service providers. The fund will allocate 60% of its resources to least developed countries, 30% to developing nations, and 10% to developed countries.
reference: "The digital divide is rapidly closing," the World Bank report said."Developing countries are catching up with the rich world in terms of access [to mobile networks]," the report said.But a spokesman for the UN's World Summit on the Information Society said the digital divide remained very real.The "digital divide" between rich and poor nations is narrowing fast, according to a World Bank report."People in the developing world are getting more access at an incredible rate - far faster than... in the past," said the report.A spokesman for the World Summit for the Information Society (WSIS), which is meeting this week in Geneva, told the BBC News website: "The digital divide is very much real and needs to be addressed."The fund is voluntary and will help finance local community-based projects," said the WSIS spokesman.
